prompts.prompt_1: A journalist investigating a corrupt corporation discovers a dangerous conspiracy that threatens their life.
prompts.prompt_2: A veterinarian in a small town uncovers a dark secret about their beloved community.
prompts.prompt_3: A chef competing on a popular cooking show must overcome sabotage and betrayal to win the prize.
prompts.prompt_4: A social worker fights to save a young child from a neglectful home, but they must navigate a complicated legal system to do so.
prompts.prompt_5: A musician with stage fright must find the courage to perform in front of a huge audience.
prompts.prompt_6: A soldier returns home from war, but they struggle to adjust to civilian life.
prompts.prompt_7: A psychologist treating a patient with dissociative identity disorder begins to question their own sanity when their patient's alter egos become too real.
prompts.prompt_8: An environmental activist fights against a powerful corporation that's destroying the planet.
prompts.prompt_9: A detective investigates a string of murders in a small town, but they soon realize that the killer may be closer than they think.
prompts.prompt_10: A programmer creates an AI system that becomes self-aware and starts to question its existence.
prompts.prompt_11: A nurse working in a busy hospital saves lives every day, but they struggle to maintain their own mental health.
prompts.prompt_12: A mountaineer attempts to climb the tallest peak in the world, but they face unexpected challenges along the way.
prompts.prompt_13: A lawyer defends a client they believe to be innocent, but they must navigate a corrupt legal system to prove their case.
prompts.prompt_14: A scientist makes a groundbreaking discovery that could change the world, but they must keep it out of the wrong hands.
prompts.prompt_15: An astronaut on a mission to explore a distant planet discovers an alien civilization.
prompts.prompt_16: A firefighter struggles to save a burning building and the lives inside, but they must also confront their own personal demons.
prompts.prompt_17: A teacher in a rough inner-city school inspires their students to learn and dream big.
prompts.prompt_18: A detective investigates a murder in a remote small town, but they find that the townspeople are keeping a dark secret.
prompts.prompt_19: A journalist working undercover uncovers a scandal that rocks a major corporation.
prompts.prompt_20: A politician fights against corruption in government, but they must also battle their own demons and past mistakes.
prompts.prompt_21: An artist struggles to create their masterpiece, but they find inspiration in an unlikely place.
prompts.prompt_22: A CEO discovers a plot to overthrow their company and must fight to keep control.
prompts.prompt_23: A chef opens their own restaurant, but they face fierce competition and personal struggles.
prompts.prompt_24: A police officer investigates a series of burglaries, but they soon realize that the thief is someone they know personally.
prompts.prompt_25: A doctor must make a difficult ethical decision that could save one life but endanger another.

storyline.step0: Welcome to StoryLine! Here's a quick tour to get you on your way.
storyline.step1: If you want to review the license, here it is.
storyline.step2: You can also find the link to the repo, if you'd like to help with translations.
storyline.step3: These are global settings for the appearance of StoryLine and the editor
storyline.step4: Change StoryLine's font, theme and light/dark mode here
storyline.step5: Change the editor's font and formatting in here
storyline.step6: If you'd like to backup StoryLine, restore a backup or have a specific work you'd like to backup or restore, you can do it in here
storyline.step7: Anything restored in here is final and irreversible!
storyline.step8: If you have a work somewhere else, you may be able to import it here
storyline.step9: Imports won't always be complete, it depends on the source
storyline.step10: Click here to create a new work and then look for the tour icon on the top left if you'd like to continue the tour

work.welcome: Welcome to your work! Because there's a lot to see, the tour is screen-specific: click the tour icon whenever you'd like more information about what's in view

navigation.section: This is where you can write your work. For more information - click this icon to view a panel of tools and then start the tour again
navigation.character: If you'd like to add information about characters, you can do it in here - click this icon to view the characters panel and then start the tour again
navigation.location: If you'd like to add information about locations, you can do it in here - click this icon to view the locations panel and then start the tour again
navigation.item: If you'd like to add information about items, you can do it in here - click this icon to view the items panel and then start the tour again
navigation.note: If you'd like to add notes, you can do it in here - click this icon to view the notes panel and then start the tour again
navigation.search: Search your work and/or or the characters, locations, items and notes associated with it - click this icon to view the search panel and then start the tour again
navigation.overview: A summary of your work in an easy to parse list, plus a timeline of events if dates have been given
navigation.connection: Map your characters, items, locations and notes to help visualise their connections
navigation.insight: A collection of stats on word count, writing patterns and narrative
navigation.export: When your work's ready for publishing, you can export it here in a variety of formats
navigation.settings: Change the title of your work, give it a cover, and more

section.intro: Your work can be split into parts, chapters and scenes (or just chapters and scenes) if you like, but it can stay as a single scene if you prefer. To re-order or move, just drag and drop.
section.addPart: Parts are a collection of chapters. Your work has one automatically, but if you want another click this icon.
section.addChapter: Chapters are a collection of scenes. Your work has one automatically, but if you want another click this icon.
section.addScene: A scene where you do your writing - it might just be a few hundred words, or it may be the entire work. Your work has one automatically, but if you want another click this icon.
section.startSprint: If you'd like to challenge yourself, you can create a sprint with a word goal and a time limit. Only words in scenes are counted!
section.view: Clicking part or chapter headings will show the content under them, clicking a scene heading will take you to the editor.If you need to edit your part, chapter or scene title or summaries, click the pencil icon instead
section.addNote: You can click this icon to add a note to part, chapter or scene

character.intro: The character panel is an optional tool that gives you a space to flesh out your characters and, if you do, you'll be able to tag them in scenes and connections.Characters can be primary, secondary or tertiary - there's no practical difference between them, it's for categorising only
character.addPrimary: A primary character is a central figure or protagonist, who plays a significant role in driving the plot forward - click this icon to add one
character.addSecondary: A secondary character supports the primary character and adds depth and complexity, but typically has a lesser role and impact - click this icon to add one.
character.addTertiary: A tertiary character is a minor, background, character who has minimal impact on the main plot, but may provide additional context or support - click this icon to add one.

location.intro: The location panel is an optional tool that gives you a space to any locations referenced in your work and, if you do, you'll be able to tag them in scenes and connections.Once you have a location, re-run this part of the tour for more information
location.add: Click this icon to add a top-level location - perhaps a country, or a town. You'll be able to add child locations under it after you save.
location.view: Click here to view the information about this location, as well as any child locations under it
location.addLocation: Click this icon to add a child location. For example, if the parent is city, it may be a park within it
location.addNote: Click this icon to add a note to the location

item.intro: The item panel is an optional tool that gives you a space to add any items referenced in your work and, if you do, you'll be able to tag them in scenes and connections.Once you have an item, re-run this part of the tour for more information
item.add: Click this icon to add an item - a magic ring, a car, who knows?
item.view: Click here to view the information about this item
item.addNote: Click this icon to add a note to the item

note.intro: The note panel is an optional tool that gives you a space to add any notes and, if you do, you'll be able to tag them in scenes and connections.Only notes that aren't related to the narrative, character, items or locations are listed here. Other notes can be found in their respective parent views.Once you have a note, re-run this part of the tour for more information
note.add: Click this icon to add a top-level note - maybe 'Narrative Strands' or 'Scribbles'
note.view: Click here to view the information about this note, as well as any child notes under it
note.addNote: Click this icon to add a child note

search.intro: The search panel allows a full work word search, which can be restricted to just scenes.
search.input: Keywords should be as exact as possible, but can be partial words.

connection.intro: This area is where you can connect anything to anything else in graphical map. The connections might be family-based (parent, sibling) or more loosely defined: 'lives in' or 'owns'.
connection.new: Create a connection between two entities here - it can be mutual, or just one way
connection.switch: Filter connections to familial-only and display in a more hierarchical view

dashboard.intro: This is your dashboard, it may not look too interesting at the moment, but the more you write the more it will grow
dashboard.chart: A quick look at activity in the last week - you'll find much more in the insights area
dashboard.tracker: An overview of your entire work, with progress if word goal has been set and days left if deadlines have been set
dashboard.lastUpdate: A list of your most recent updates
dashboard.deadline: Your five closest deadlines, if you're using them
dashboard.random: A character name and personality generator and a prompter to get the gears turning

export.intro: You work is exportable in a variety of formats, but by their nature they may not all have the same configration options.

location.map: If your location exists, you can click the map to automatically get its coordinates. Or, click the icon directly to the map's right to enter the coordinates yourself.

note.color: To help organise them, notes can be given a colour
note.taggable: If you want your note to be available to reference in scenes or connections, check this box

overview.intro: The overview summary is a brief rundown of part, scene and chapter, using any descriptive text, tags and excerpts to build itselfThe timeline is a graphical representation of events in scenes, notes and anything else that allows a date to be given (including character date of birth).To move an event, click and drag it to a new point.

scene.intro: Where the magic* happens! If you prefer to write without distractions, full-screen the app* magic may include swearing

toolbar.excerpt: Highlight text you'd like to appear on the overview summary as a reminder
toolbar.tag: While you can tag locations, characters, items and notes when editing a scene, you can also highlight text and click here
toolbar.version: Click here to add a new version of a scene, or view previous versions

work.statusWidget: If you'd like to keep track of the status of anything in your work, click one of the states on the widget to update it. The work's status won't automatically update (e.g., meeting a word goal won't make the status Complete).
